title: 105_s1236
content: The Act titled "National Police Pursuit Policy Act of 1997" is cited as the short title. In 1996, 377 deaths occurred in the US due to high-speed motor vehicle pursuits, with 103 being police officers or innocent bystanders. 40% of pursuits in 1995 resulted in accidents, 20% in injury, and 1% in death. 60% of pursuits were not related to felony offenses. Insufficient statistical data is available on high-speed pursuits. A recent study found that 73% of law enforcement officers had been involved in high-speed motor vehicle pursuits in the past year, with 40% reporting accidents resulting from these pursuits. 71% of agencies provided data on high-speed pursuits, despite only 31% maintaining consistent records. Recent studies have shown that law enforcement recruits receive minimal training in driving skills, with a focus on mechanics rather than safe high-speed pursuit procedures. However, increased emphasis on pursuit policies and training reduces the occurrence of high-speed pursuits among trained recruits. SEC. 3. MOTOR VEHICLE PURSUIT REQUIREMENTS FOR STATE HIGHWAY SAFETY PROGRAMS. Section 402(b)(1) of title 23, United States Code is amended to include a new subparagraph requiring states to have a law in effect from January 1, 1999, that prohibits drivers from increasing speed or taking evasive action when signaled by law enforcement to stop their vehicle. Violators of this law will face penalties. The law requires states to have a policy in place for motor vehicle pursuits, including penalties for violators such as imprisonment, vehicle seizure, and enforcement agency compliance with pursuit guidelines set by the Secretary. The law mandates states to have a policy for motor vehicle pursuits, including penalties for violators and enforcement agency compliance with pursuit guidelines. Law enforcement agencies must conduct pursuits according to the policy, train all officers, and report on each pursuit annually. Law enforcement agencies must conduct pursuits according to the policy, train all officers, and report on each pursuit annually. Reporting requirement. The law requires various government agencies to report their policies on motor vehicle pursuits by law enforcement officers and the training procedures they use. These policies must meet the standards set by the Secretary of Transportation. Transportation pursuant to section 402(b)(1)(F)(ii)(I) of title 23, United States Code, regarding motor vehicle pursuit conduct.
